channel.title: Logical Equivalence :: CIS 301 Textbook
channel.description: Two (or more) logical statements are said to be logically equivalent IFF (if and only if, ↔) they have the same truth value for every truth assignment; i.e., their truth tables evaluate exactly the same. (We sometimes refer to this as semantic equivalence.) An example of logically equivalent statements are q ∧ p and p ∧ (q ∧ p): * -------------- p q # (p ∧ q) -------------- T T # T T F # F F T # F F F # F --------------- Contingent T: [T T] F: [F F] [F T] [T F] * ------------------- p q # p ∧ (q ∧ p) ------------------- T T # T T T F # F F F T # F F F F # F F -------------------- Contingent T : [T T] F : [F F] [F T] [T F]In these examples, notice that exactly the same set of truth assignments makes both statements true, and that exactly the same set of truth assignments makes both statements false.
